titleStmt.title: Draft of Keats' "I Stood Tip-Toe Upon a Little Hill"

figure.figDesc: crosshatch doodles appear at top of page and along left-hand margin

lg.l: Sometimes Gold. finches one by one will drop
From low hung Branch little space they stop
But sip and twitter and their feathers sleaksleek
Then off they go as in a wonton freak

l.del: And as they come and go but small their wings
So lovely for their yellow flutterings

lg.l: Or perhaps to show the Beauty of their wings
Pausing when their yellow flutterings
Were I in such a place I sure would pray
That nought less sweet might call my thoughts away
Than the soft Rustling of a Maiden's gown
Sweeping away the Dandelion's down

l.del: Than her light tripping oer the

lg.l: Than the light Music of her nimble toes
20Patting against the Sorrel as she goes

l.del: How she will start and blush thus to be caught

lg.l: How she will start and blush thus to be caught
Playing in all her innocence of thought
O let me lead her gently o'er the Brook
With her half smiling lips and downward look
O let me for one moment touch her Wrist hand
Let me one moment to her breathing list
And as she leaves me let her often turn
Her fair eyes peeping through her Locks auburn
